Exhibition.ExhibitionName: World Museum Liverpool Sierra Leone Collection

CulturalObject.Description: A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is woven with brown and undyed fibres. It has a chequerboard design.
This woven basket-like item is described in the World Museum Liverpool as a sieve, or sifter.

This is a raffia skirt worn as part of the costume of the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. It is worn around the waist; other elements of the costume include the sowei mask, with raffia attached to its rim.

This is a raffia skirt worn as part of the costume of the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. It is worn around the waist; other elements of the costume include the sowei mask, with raffia attached to its rim.
A cane basket.

A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is woven with dark and light fibres, and has an enlarged handle on top of the lid.

This resembles a carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a diamond shaped head, often associated with Gola examples from the Sierra Leone-Liberia border. Her three-lobed hairstyle is surmounted by a pyramid shaped object, likely to be a protective sebe/sebbeh , or amulet.

A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is woven with dark and light fibres.

CulturalObject.Description: A cup, or ladle, made out of a gourd, or calabash.

A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This larger example is woven with faded red, brown and undyed, fibres. It has a geometric design.

A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This larger example is woven with faded red, brown and undyed, fibres. It has an intricate geometric design.

This resembles a carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example comes from Moyamba, and has distinctive circular eyes. Her hairstyle is adorned with rows of cowrie-shells, associated with power and wealth.

A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is woven with dark and light fibres, and a plaited cord is attached to the lid.

CulturalObject.Description: A gourd, or calabash, container, probably for storing water, or poyo (palm wine).

This bow was originally accessioned along with a stringed instrument described as a violin made of a gourd covered with lizard skin, which has now been lost. This was most likely a one-stringed instrument called a nyayaru in Foulah, gbulu in Temne, kuliktu in Limba and kalani in Mandingo. The nyayaru has part of a gourd for its sound box, a stick for its neck and a bunch of stretched hair for its string. A snake or iguana skin is stretched across the top of the gourd and a small stick is wedged in between the string and skin to act as a bridge.
A wooden horn, thought to have been used by the Mende during the Ashanti campaign in 1900. It has a string carrying strap.
This is thought to be a cigarette case, made from plaited an dyed raffia.
This is thought to be a cigarette case, made from plaited an dyed raffia.

This resembles a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness; this example is labelled a Yassi figure . They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has a typical segmented neck, and wears a lappa, or skirt, around her waist.

This is a carved representation of a female figure, standing on a plinth. She has a typical segmented neck and ridged hairstyle, and has been painted black. The original World Museum Liverpool record reads King Sabbaho wife, JuJu, or God, from the town of Tobiah, interior of Sherbro country.

This is a raffia skirt worn as part of the costume of the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. It is worn around the waist; other elements of the costume include the sowei mask, with raffia attached to its rim.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Sierra Leone: Kenema District: Kenema (Created and collected)

CulturalObject.Description: A basket work hat, with an unusually wide brim, decorated with raised basketwork lines.
This appears to be a bamboo plaited hat, but could also be a dish cover.
A conical cap, made from woven raffia, or grass. It has a tassel attached to the top.
A wide-brim hat, made from coiled basket work, covered in loose raffia. It has two bands of raised, tufted, raffia around the top, and the brim.

This is a hammock, composed of strips of country cloth that have been sewn together. Country cloth is traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. Hammocks, such as this one, were often used to transport high status individuals on ceremonial occasions. It would have been supported by poles, which may also have held a wooden canopy
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Sierra Leone: Sherbro District (Created and collected)

CulturalObject.Description: This resembles a carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a domed shape, and a crease running across the eyes; its features are carved in relatively low relief. The hairstyle is represented by rows of small circular bumps, and surmounted by a pyramid shaped object, possibly representing a sebe/sebbeh , or amulet. It is complete with its raffia skirt. The mask was collected by Alfred C. Williams, a Krio engineer and trader, based in Freetown.

This is a carved wooden ceremonial staff. On the top of the staff is a carved female head with particularly long segmented neck, and a ridged hairstyle. The staff was collected by Alfred C. Williams, a Krio engineer and trader, based in Freetown.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Sierra Leone: Kenema District: Blama (Created and collected)

CulturalObject.Description: This resembles a carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This is an early eastern Mende example, with a particularly high forehead and an oval, ridged, mouth. She has a three lobed hairstyle, and is accompanied by raffia, attached through holes drilled around the bottom, as well as the woven cloth trousers and shirt. The staff was collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister.

A wooden carving of an animal on its hind legs, probably a leopard, or a monkey. It is decorated with spots, burnt onto its surface. The carving was collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister who spent many years based in Freetown.

A woven rattan fan. Fans, like this one, have a number of different uses such as fanning away pounded rice husks or roasted peanut skins. The fan was collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister who spent many years based in Freetown.

A soft wood spoon with burnt designs on the handle, and around the rim of the spoon. Wooden spoons, like this one, have been called rice scoops in other collections, for example, those held by Glasgow Museums. The spoon was collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister who spent many years based in Freetown.

A circular tin, covered with red leather, and decorated with inlayed geometric bands of woven red and undyed fibres. This example is typical of Muslim Sierra Leonean leatherwork in the provinces, commonly known as Mandingo . The original notes from the donor described it as a Cigarette Cup . The tin was collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister who spent many years based in Freetown.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Metal; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A large jug, made from stoneware, a type of clay. It is decorated with a band of typical Mandingo leatherwork. Mandingo , used here, refers to a style of decoration associated with Muslim elites. The jug was collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister who spent many years based in Freetown.
CulturalObject.Materials: Ceramic; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: This unusual wooden carving depicts a British Government Official. It was made in Kenema. The carving was collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister who spent many years based in Freetown.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Sierra Leone: Kenema District (Collected and created)

CulturalObject.Description: This resembles a carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has an unusual hairstyle with a single lobe, surrounded by ridged circles. The mask is Janus-faced, with a diamond shaped face carved on either side of its head. It is carved in a Gola style, commonly associated with masks from Liberia. The mask was collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister who spent many years based in Freetown.

One of three wooden combs, each with eight prongs. The comb bases of these combs are all incised with a geometric, hatched, design, and have sets of T-shaped blocks adorning the handle. The combs were collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister who spent many years based in Freetown.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Sierra Leone: Sherbro District (Created and collected)

CulturalObject.Description: This is a carving of two female figures, attached to a stand. They are identical, bar their heads, which have individual facial features and hairstyles. Both figures are wearing two sets of beads around their necks. The carving was collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister who spent many years based in Freetown.

A wooden carving of a bird, mounted onto a wooden stand; possibly a later addition. It is decorated with incised linear patterns, representing plumage. The World Museum Liverpool catalogue describes it as an ostrich. The carving was collected by C.D. Hotobah During, a well-known Krio Barrister who spent many years based in Freetown.

This is a charm, or magical object, consisting of a gourd containing magical substances, potentially palm oil. It is bound with string and an unidentified substance, adorned with cowrie shells and quills. The World Museum Liverpool catalogue records it as a Poorah fetish ; Poorah may be a different spelling of Poro.

This is a charm, or magical object, consisting of a tortoise shell, containing magical substances, herbs, or medicines. It is attached to a piece of leather, woven cotton, and grass. The World Museum Liverpool catalogue records it as a Poorah fetish ; Poorah may be a different spelling of Poro.
CulturalObject.Materials: Bone, ivory, tooth; Vegetable, organic fibre; Textile; Unknown

CulturalObject.Description: A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a typical ridged hairstyle, with three lobes. There are scarification marks on either side of the eyes, and a ring of holes around the base for attaching raffia.

A unusual carved wooden comb. It has seven long prongs attached to a tooth-base with a series of holes bored into it. Attached to the handle is a carved chain, linking the comb to a representation of a small boat. The comb was collected by G. P. During, a well-known Krio money lender and businessman who worked in Freetown and Bok in French Guine.

A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is woven with green and blue fibres.

CulturalObject.Description: A broad rimmed hat, made from coils of raffia, in three colours. It is decorated with stripes running around the hat, and geometric designs.

CulturalObject.Description: A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has unusually carved neck rings and a small, un-detailed, face. It does not have any raffia holes, so may have been carved for sale, rather than use.

A wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a typical ridged hairstyle with a single lobe, and vertical scarification marks underneath her eyes.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has an unusual hairstyle with a single lobe, surrounded by ridged circles.

This is very ornate example of a 16th century carved ivory horn. The mouthpiece at the tip of the horn is depicted emerging from the fanged jaws of an animal head, following through to the body of the horn, which is covered in low relief carving. This section includes fantastical European creatures, and African animals such as crocodiles and serpents. The base of the horn is carved with the Coat of Arms of the Portuguese royal house. It is very similar to an example at the British Museum, accession number BM:Af.1979.1.3156. This is an example of an Afro-Portuguese ivory, a term used to indicate items from Sierra Leone and Nigeria, made for a Portuguese market in the 15th and 16th centuries. Such items display a mixture of African and European elements and motifs in their overall form and ornamentation, and were considered prestige items across Europe. A more specific term for items patronised in Sierra Leone, is Sapi-Portuguese.

A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This larger example is woven with red, brown and undyed, fibres.

A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is woven with dark and light fibres, and a plaited cord is attached to the lid. Larger baskets, such as this one, are often used to store clothing, and they were given to future Krio brides at their engagements.

This is a horn, containing magical substances, herbs, or medicines. It is thought to have been used by the Tongo Players, a name given to a group of professional witch finders who were called in to investigate and detect members of the Leopard Society, blamed for a series of murders in Imperri chiefdom in the early 1890s. All Tongo activity was later banned by the British Colonial Government.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Sierra Leone: Sherbro District (Collected and created)

CulturalObject.Description: This is a tortoise shell, containing magical substances, herbs, or medicines. It is thought to have been used by the Tongo Players, a name given to a group of professional witch finders who were called in to investigate and detect members of the Leopard Society, blamed for a series of murders in Imperri chiefdom in the early 1890s. All Tongo activity was later banned by the British Colonial Government. The original catalogue entry from World Museum Liverpool reads medicine to make the man who is going to strike the criminal not afraid. Puts (it) to his heart before he strikes.

CulturalObject.Description: This is a belt, or strap, made from a length of woven cotton cloth, to which are attached 9 bells. It is thought to have been used by the Tongo Players, a name given to a group of professional witch finders who were called in to investigate and detect members of the Leopard Society, blamed for a series of murders in Imperri chiefdom in the early 1890s. All Tongo activity was later banned by the British Colonial Government. The World Museum Liverpool catalogue notes that this item was worn by the Hakawa of the Tongo Players.

CulturalObject.Description: This hat has been made by coiled plaits of light and dark raffia, or grass. It has an unusually square top. The World Museum Liverpool catalogue associated this example with hats made by initiatives into the all male Poro society, in the Poro bush .

A conical cap, made from tapa , or bark cloth, covered with red and black cloth, and surmounted by a tuft of animal hair. It resembles caps worn by dancers and public performers, such s sampa dancers of the Sande and Bundu societies.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Sierra Leone: Sherbro District (Created and collected)

CulturalObject.Description: This gown is composed of strips of cream and light blue country cloth, sewn together to make a striped gown. This example is thought to have been worn by the chief officer of the Tongo Players, Gbowa-mo-Nepo

This is shirt, made from strips of woven country cloth, with sebe/sebbeh , or amulets, attached under the arms. It is thought to have been used by the Tongo Players, a name given to a group of professional witch finders who were called in to investigate and detect members of the Leopard Society, blamed for a series of murders in Imperri chiefdom in the early 1890s. All Tongo activity was later banned by the British Colonial Government. This shirt was worn by the Kondo , the Kondo was known for fixing the fees for the services of the Tongo Players.

This is a pair of drawstring trousers, made from strips of woven country cloth. They are thought to have been used by the Tongo Players, a name given to a group of professional witch finders who were called in to investigate and detect members of the Leopard Society, blamed for a series of murders in Imperri chiefdom in the early 1890s. All Tongo activity was later banned by the British Colonial Government. This pair of trousers was worn by the Jahu Wele , the chief dancer, who announced the proceedings and assembled the people. Jahu Wele comes from the Mende for water road , and was used here to denote the dancer s key role in assembling women who were out fetching water.

This is a Tongara or killing club used by the Kondo of the Tongo Players. It is made of wood, bound with hide and raffia. Tongo Players, was a name given to a group of professional witch finders who were called in to investigate and detect members of the Leopard Society, blamed for a series of murders in Imperri chiefdom in the early 1890s. All Tongo activity was later banned by the British Colonial Government. The Tongara was thought to be used in the accusation of witches; it would be shaken up and down on the ground until it selected the accused. The Kondo is otherwise associated with being the fee collector.
CulturalObject.Materials: Wood; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre; Metal

CulturalObject.Description: A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This unusual example is woven with dark and light fibres, and has a funnelled neck.

A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is woven with dark and light fibres, with a chequered pattern around the sides. It has three plaited fibre loops attached to the lid.

This is one of a pair covered bowls. It has been carved in the shape of a sitting chicken, or fowl, and are decorated with burnt circular designs.The bowl was collected by Miss B. Yorke, a Krio trader.

This is one of a pair covered bowls. It has been carved in the shape of a sitting chicken, or fowl, and are decorated with burnt circular designs.The bowl was collected by Miss B. Yorke, a Krio trader.

A woven brimmed hat, made from plaited fibres died in dark drown and red. Tufted grasses are attached along the brim. The World Museum Liverpool describe this item as a rain hat . The hat was collected by Miss B. Yorke, a Krio trader.
A chipped stone hand-axe, made from Jadeite

This is a plaited grass dish cover, to keep prepared food free from flies and other insects. It is decorated with horizontal stripes in dyed raffia, and has a small loop attached to the top for lifting.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness; this example is labelled a Yassi figure . They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has a typical segmented neck, and wears a set of red waist beads.
This is a bamboo staff, ornately decorated with repeated incisions. The decoration represents a series of human faces.

A woven brimmed hat, made from plaited fibres died in dark drown and red. Tufted grasses are attached along the brim. A similar hat in the World Museum Liverpool is described as a rain hat . The hat was collected by Mrs. W. E. Johnson, a Krio trader.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Mrs. W. E. Johnson (Collector); A. Ridyard (Donor)

CulturalObject.Description: This is a carved ivory tusk, decorated with two incised lines. It has two holes incised at the mouth.

This resembles a carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example is Janus faced and has a cross-hatched hairstyle, with three lobes, tied with white fabric.

A carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a typical ridged hairstyle, with five lobes. She has scarification marks on her cheeks, and pierced ears.

This is an eight-panelled peaked cap made from woven raffia, with a cotton lining. A Krio craftsman is likely to have made this cap, based on a European design. Quality European-style clothing was an important mark of status and success among the Krio.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: Sierra Leone: Western Peninsula (Created and collected)

CulturalObject.Description: This gown is composed of strips of cream and dark blue country cloth, sewn together to make a striped gown. Country cloth is traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige.

Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has a typical ridged hairstyle, and holes representing eyes, ears and the mouth.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.

Leg or arm rattles worn by dances and other public performers. They are made from a flat oval piece of iron that is bent over to form a rattle. There is a loop at each end, with two additional loops attached to it that rattle when the wearer moves. The original label accompanying the rattles notes that they were used in initiation ceremonies of Hu , associated with the exclusively male Poro society.

This resembles a carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has scarification marks on her forehead, shaped like a cross. Her five-lobed hairstyle is adorned with rows of cowrie-shells, associated with power and wealth.

This may be a very damaged minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness; this example is labelled a Yassi figure . They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example is missing both arms, and her left foot, but has the typical segmented neck and ridged hairstyle.

CulturalObject.Description: This is a coiled raffia basket from Ibi in Northern Nigeria. It is included as it was originally collected by a member of Sierra Leone s Krio community, John. G. Taylor. From the mid-nineteenth century, Krio traders, missionaries and professionals settled along the coast of West Africa and in settlements on the Niger River. This Krio diaspora maintained close links with Sierra Leone through steam shipping lines, and objects from throughout the region found their way to Freetown where they were sometimes acquired by European collectors.

A brass jug, taken in the Bida war in Northern Nigeria. It is included as it was originally collected by a member of Sierra Leone s Krio community, E. A. T. Wilson. This Krio diaspora maintained close links with Sierra Leone through steam shipping lines, and objects from throughout the region found their way to Freetown where they were sometimes acquired by European collectors. E. A. T Wilson was a trader, based in Freetown.

A double wooden bowl, used to serve pepper and salt. Though it was made in Nigeria, it is included as it was originally collected by a member of Sierra Leone s Krio community, Archdeacon D. C. Crowther, son of Bishop Crowther, the first Anglican Bishop in Nigeria. From the mid-nineteenth century, Krio traders, missionaries and professionals settled along the coast of West Africa and in settlements on the Niger River. This Krio diaspora maintained close links with Sierra Leone through steam shipping lines, and objects from throughout the region found their way to Freetown where they were sometimes acquired by European collectors. CulturalObject.Description: This is a Nigerian ivory horn, originally described as a juju horn . Though it was made in Nigeria, it is included as it was originally collected by a member of Sierra Leone s Krio community, Archdeacon D. C. Crowther, son of Bishop Crowther, the first Anglican Bishop in Nigeria. From the mid-nineteenth century, Krio traders, missionaries and professionals settled along the coast of West Africa and in settlements on the Niger River. This Krio diaspora maintained close links with Sierra Leone through steam shipping lines, and objects from throughout the region found their way to Freetown where they were sometimes acquired by European collectors. Archdeacon D. C. Crowther led the Niger Delta Pastorate Mission at Bonny and became part of the independent African church movement in 1892. Crowther s original description reads This ivory horn is always blown in olden times at the juju skull house at Bonny (said to have been 150 years old) whenever the annual worship of Ikuber is on it is never blown except when a human sacrifice is offered This worship was abolished since 1865 when the mission was established at Bonny and this horn delivered up .
CulturalObject.AssociatedPlaces: South Eastern Nigeria: Bonny (Collected and created)
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Rev. Archdeacon D.C. Crowther (Collector); A. Ridyard (Donor)
